bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Clerical Union (formerly known as the Clerical Society of the City of Brooklyn) was formed on January 29, 1844 through the efforts of Maurice W. Dwight. The Union's mission was to promote Christian love and confidence among the ministers of the various religious denominations in Brooklyn. The five founding officers were Reverend Maurice W. Dwight, First Reformed Dutch Church, President; Reverend J.L. Hodge, First Baptist Church, Vice-President; Reverend J. Poisal, Methodist (church unknown), Secretary; and Reverend George Duffield, Fifth Presbyterian Church, Treasurer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooklyn Clerical Union minute books and scrapbook span the dates 1844 to 1940 and measure .77 linear feet. The collection contains the records of the Brooklyn Clerical Union (formerly known as the Clerical Society of the City of Brooklyn). Included are eight volumes of minute books, the first of which contains the Union's original constitution, bylaws, and membership list. The membership list includes dates of birth and dates of ordination. Seven volumes, dating from 1844 to 1931, are handwritten. The remaining volume is typed and spans the dates 1932 to 1940. The scrapbook, titled Letters and Manuscripts and Historical Sketches by A. DeW. Mason and J. Frederic Berg, dates from 1870 to 1934.
Box 1 contains: six minute books dated 1844 to 1858; 1867 to 1875; 1876 to 1883; 1894 to 1900; 1900 to 1907; and 1907 to 1923.
Box 2 contains: two minute books dated 1923 to 1932 and 1932 to 1940; and one scrapbook, 1870 to 1934.
